00035 # Utility macro

00037 
00038 =head2  Utility Macros
00039 
00040 
00041 =head4  not_null
00042      
00043   not_null(item)  returns 1 or 0
00044      
00045      empty arrays, empty hashes, strings containing only whitespace are all NULL and return 0
00046      all undefined quantities are null and return 0
00047 
00048 
00049 =cut
00050 
00051 sub not_null {        # empty arrays, empty hashes and strings containing only whitespace are all NULL
00052     my $item = shift;
00053     return 0 unless defined($item);
00054     if (ref($item)=~/ARRAY/) {
00055         return scalar(@{$item});     # return the length    
00056     } elsif (ref($item)=~/HASH/) {
00057         return scalar( keys %{$item});
00058     } else {   # string case return 1 if none empty 
00059       return ($item =~ /\S/)? 1:0;
00060     }
00061 }
00062 
00063 =head4 pretty_print
00064 
00065     Usage: warn pretty_print( $rh_hash_input)
00066            TEXT(pretty_print($ans_hash));
00067            TEXT(pretty_print(~~%envir ));
00068 
00069 This can be very useful for printing out HTML messages about objects while debugging
00070 
00071 =cut
00072 
00073 # ^function pretty_print
00074 # ^uses lex_sort
00075 # ^uses pretty_print
00076 sub pretty_print {    # provides html output -- NOT a method
00077     my $r_input = shift;
00078     my $level = shift;
00079     $level = 4 unless defined($level);
00080     $level--;
00081     return '' unless $level > 0;  # only print three levels of hashes (safety feature)
00082     my $out = '';
00083     if ( not ref($r_input) ) {
00084         $out = $r_input if defined $r_input;    # not a reference
00085         $out =~ s/</&lt;/g  ;  # protect for HTML output
00086     } elsif ("$r_input" =~/hash/i) {  # this will pick up objects whose '$self' is hash and so works better than ref($r_iput).
00087         local($^W) = 0;
00088         
00089         $out .= "$r_input " ."<TABLE border = \"2\" cellpadding = \"3\" BGCOLOR = \"#FFFFFF\">";
00090         
00091         
00092         foreach my $key ( sort ( keys %$r_input )) {
00093             $out .= "<tr><TD> $key</TD><TD>=&gt;</td><td>&nbsp;".pretty_print($r_input->{$key}) . "</td></tr>";
00094         }
00095         $out .="</table>";
00096     } elsif (ref($r_input) eq 'ARRAY' ) {
00097         my @array = @$r_input;
00098         $out .= "( " ;
00099         while (@array) {
00100             $out .= pretty_print(shift @array, $level) . " , ";
00101         }
00102         $out .= " )";
00103     } elsif (ref($r_input) eq 'CODE') {
00104         $out = "$r_input";
00105     } else {
00106         $out = $r_input;
00107         $out =~ s/</&lt;/g; # protect for HTML output
00108     }
00109         $out;
00110 }

00115 sub new {
00116     my $class = shift;  
00117     my $envir = shift;  #pointer to environment hash
00118     warn "PGcore must be called with an environment" unless ref($envir) eq 'HASH';
00119     #warn "creating a new PGcore object";
00120     my %options = @_;
00121     my $self = {
00122         OUTPUT_ARRAY              => [],          # holds output body text
00123         HEADER_ARRAY              => [],         # holds output for the header text
00124         POST_HEADER_ARRAY         => [],
00125 #       PG_ANSWERS                => [],  # holds answers with labels # deprecated
00126 #       PG_UNLABELED_ANSWERS      => [],  # holds unlabeled ans. #deprecated -replaced by PG_ANSWERS_HASH
00127         PG_ANSWERS_HASH           => {},  # holds label=>answer pairs
00128         PERSISTENCE_HASH           => {}, # holds other data, besides answers, which persists during a session and beyond
00129         answer_eval_count         => 0,
00130         answer_blank_count        => 0,
00131         unlabeled_answer_blank_count =>0,
00132         unlabeled_answer_eval_count  => 0,
00133         KEPT_EXTRA_ANSWERS        => [],
00134         ANSWER_PREFIX             => 'AnSwEr',
00135         ARRAY_PREFIX              => 'ArRaY',
00136         vec_num                   => 0,     # for distinguishing matrices
00137         QUIZ_PREFIX               => $envir->{QUIZ_PREFIX},
00138         SECTION_PREFIX            => '',  # might be used for sequential (compound) questions?
00139         
00140         PG_ACTIVE                 => 1,   # toggle to zero to stop processing
00141         submittedAnswers          => 0,   # have any answers been submitted? is this the first time this session?
00142         PG_session_persistence_hash =>{}, # stores data from one invoction of the session to the next.
00143         PG_original_problem_seed  => 0,
00144         PG_random_generator       => undef,
00145         PG_alias                  => undef,
00146         PG_problem_grader         => undef,
00147         displayMode               => undef,
00148         envir                     => $envir,
00149         WARNING_messages          => [],
00150         DEBUG_messages            => [],
00151         gifs_created              => {},
00152         external_refs             => {},      # record of external references 
00153         %options,                                   # allows overrides and initialization   
00154     };
00155     bless $self, $class;
00156     tie %{$self->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}}, "Tie::IxHash";  # creates a Hash with order
00157     $self->initialize;
00158     return $self;
00159 }
00160 
00161 sub initialize {
00162     my $self = shift;
00163     warn "environment is not defined in PGcore" unless ref($self->{envir}) eq 'HASH';
00164     
00165     
00166     
00167     
00168     $self->{displayMode}                = $self->{envir}->{displayMode};
00169     $self->{PG_original_problem_seed}   = $self->{envir}->{problemSeed};
00170     $self->{PG_random_generator}        = new PGrandom( $self->{PG_original_problem_seed});
00171 
00172     $self->{tempDirectory}        = $self->{envir}->{tempDirectory};
00173     $self->{PG_problem_grader}    = $self->{envir}->{PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE};
00174     $self->{PG_alias}             = PGalias->new($self->{envir},
00175                                         WARNING_messages => $self->{WARNING_messages},
00176                                         DEBUG_messages   => $self->{DEBUG_messages},
00177                                                  
00178     );
00179     $self->{PG_loadMacros}        = new PGloadfiles($self->{envir});
00180     $self->{flags} = {
00181         showpartialCorrectAnswers => 1,
00182         showHint                  => 1,
00183         hintExists                => 0,
00184         showHintLimit             => 0,
00185         solutionExists            => 0,
00186         recordSubmittedAnswers    => 1,
00187         refreshCachedImages       => 0,
00188 #       ANSWER_ENTRY_ORDER        => [],  # may not be needed if we ue Tie:IxHash
00189         comment                   => '',  # implement as array?
00190 
00191     
00192     
00193     };
00194 
00195 }

00198 ####################################################################
00199 
00200 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00201 
00202 This file provides the fundamental macros that define the PG language. It
00203 maintains a problem's text, header text, and answers:
00204 
00205 =over
00206 
00207 =item *
00208 
00209 Problem text: The text to appear in the body of the problem. See TEXT()
00210 below.
00211 
00212 =item *
00213 
00214 Header text: When a problem is processed in an HTML-based display mode,
00215 this variable can contain text that the caller should place in the HEAD of the
00216 resulting HTML page. See HEADER_TEXT() below.
00217 
00218 =item *
00219 
00220 Implicitly-labeled answers: Answers that have not been explicitly
00221 assigned names, and are associated with their answer blanks by the order in
00222 which they appear in the problem. These types of answers are designated using
00223 the ANS() macro.
00224 
00225 =item *
00226 
00227 Explicitly-labeled answers: Answers that have been explicitly assigned
00228 names with the LABELED_ANS() macro, or a macro that uses it. An explicitly-
00229 labeled answer is associated with its answer blank by name.
00230 
00231 =item *
00232 
00233 "Extra" answers: Names of answer blanks that do not have a 1-to-1
00234 correspondance to an answer evaluator. For example, in matrix problems, there
00235 will be several input fields that correspond to the same answer evaluator.
00236 
00237 =back
00238 
00239 =head1 USAGE
00240 
00241 This file is automatically loaded into the namespace of every PG problem. The
00242 macros within can then be called to define the structure of the problem.
00243 
00244 DOCUMENT() should be the first executable statement in any problem. It
00245 initializes vriables and defines the problem environment.
00246 
00247 ENDDOCUMENT() must be the last executable statement in any problem. It packs
00248 up the results of problem processing for delivery back to WeBWorK.
00249 
00250 The HEADER_TEXT(), TEXT(), and ANS() macros add to the header text string,
00251 body text string, and answer evaluator queue, respectively.
00252 
00253 =cut
00254 
00255 
00256 =item HEADER_TEXT()
00257 
00258  HEADER_TEXT("string1", "string2", "string3");
00259 
00260 HEADER_TEXT() concatenates its arguments and appends them to the stored header
00261 text string. It can be used more than once in a file.
00262 
00263 The macro is used for material which is destined to be placed in the HEAD of
00264 the page when in HTML mode, such as JavaScript code.
00265 
00266 Spaces are placed between the arguments during concatenation, but no spaces are
00267 introduced between the existing content of the header text string and the new
00268 content being appended.
00269 
00270 =cut
00271 
00272 
00273 
00274 # ^function HEADER_TEXT
00275 # ^uses $STRINGforHEADER_TEXT
00276 sub HEADER_TEXT {
00277     my $self = shift;
00278     push @{$self->{HEADER_ARRAY}}, map { (defined($_) )?$_:'' } @_;
00279     $self->{HEADER_ARRAY}  ;
00280 }
00281 
00282 =item POST_HEADER_TEXT()
00283 
00284  POST_HEADER_TEXT("string1", "string2", "string3");
00285 
00286 POST_HEADER_TEXT() concatenates its arguments and appends them to the stored post_header
00287 text string. It can be used more than once in a file.
00288 
00289 The macro is used for material which is destined to be placed iimmediately after the HEAD of
00290 the page as the first item in the body, before the main problem form
00291 when in HTML mode, such as JavaScript code.
00292 
00293 Spaces are placed between the arguments during concatenation, but no spaces are
00294 introduced between the existing content of the header text string and the new
00295 content being appended.
00296 
00297 =cut
00298 
00299 # ^function POST_HEADER_TEXT
00300 # ^uses $STRINGforHEADER_TEXT
00301 sub POST_HEADER_TEXT {
00302     my $self = shift;
00303     push @{$self->{POST_HEADER_ARRAY}}, map { (defined($_) )?$_:'' } @_;
00304     $self->{POST_HEADER_ARRAY}  ;
00305 }
00306 
00307 
00308 =item TEXT()
00309 
00310  TEXT("string1", "string2", "string3");
00311 
00312 TEXT() concatenates its arguments and appends them to the stored problem text
00313 string. It is used to define the text which will appear in the body of the
00314 problem. It can be used more than once in a file.
00315 
00316 This macro has no effect if rendering has been stopped with the STOP_RENDERING()
00317 macro.
00318 
00319 This macro defines text which will appear in the problem. All text must be
00320 passed to this macro, passed to another macro that calls this macro, or included
00321 in a BEGIN_TEXT/END_TEXT block, which uses this macro internally. No other
00322 statements in a PG file will directly appear in the output. Think of this as the
00323 "print" function for the PG language.
00324 
00325 Spaces are placed between the arguments during concatenation, but no spaces are
00326 introduced between the existing content of the header text string and the new
00327 content being appended.
00328 
00329 =cut
00330 
00331 # ^function TEXT
00332 # ^uses $PG_STOP_FLAG
00333 # ^uses $STRINGforOUTPUT
00334 
00335 sub TEXT {
00336     my $self = shift;    #FIXME  filter for undefined entries replace by "";
00337     push @{$self->{OUTPUT_ARRAY}}, map { (defined($_) )?$_:'' } @_ ;
00338     $self->{OUTPUT_ARRAY};
00339 }
00340 
00341 sub envir {
00342     my $self = shift;
00343     my $in_key = shift;
00344     if ( not_null($in_key) ) {
00345         if (defined  ($self->{envir}->{$in_key} ) ) {
00346             $self->{envir}->{$in_key};
00347         } else {
00348              warn "\$envir{$in_key} is not defined\n";
00349             return '';
00350         }
00351     } else {
00352         warn "<h3> Environment</h3>".pretty_print($self->{envir});
00353         return '';
00354     }
00355 
00356 }
00357 =item LABELED_ANS()
00358 
00359  TEXT(labeled_ans_rule("name1"), labeled_ans_rule("name2"));
00360  LABELED_ANS(name1 => answer_evaluator1, name2 => answer_evaluator2);
00361 
00362 Adds the answer evaluators listed to the list of labeled answer evaluators.
00363 They will be paired with labeled answer rules (a.k.a. answer blanks) in the
00364 order entered. This allows pairing of answer evaluators and answer rules that
00365 may not have been entered in the same order.
00366 
00367 =cut
00368 
00369 # ^function NAMED_ANS
00370 # ^uses &LABELED_ANS
00371 sub NAMED_ANS {
00372     &LABELED_ANS;
00373 }
00374 
00375 =item NAMED_ANS()
00376 
00377 Old name for LABELED_ANS(). DEPRECATED.
00378 
00379 =cut
00380 
00381 # ^function NAMED_ANS
00382 # ^uses $PG_STOP_FLAG
00383 sub LABELED_ANS{ 
00384   my $self = shift;
00385   my @in = @_;
00386   while (@in ) {
00387     my $label    = shift @in;
00388     #$label       = join("", $self->{QUIZ_PREFIX}, $self->{SECTION_PREFIX}, $label);
00389     my $ans_eval = shift @in;
00390     $self->warning_message("<BR><B>Error in LABELED_ANS:|$label|</B>
00391           -- inputs must be references to AnswerEvaluator objects or subroutines<BR>")
00392             unless ref($ans_eval) =~ /CODE/ or ref($ans_eval) =~ /AnswerEvaluator/  ;
00393     if (defined($self->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$label})  ){
00394         $self->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$label}->insert(ans_label => $label, ans_eval => $ans_eval, active=>$self->{PG_ACTIVE});
00395     } else {
00396         $self->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$label} = PGanswergroup->new($label, ans_eval => $ans_eval, active=>$self->{PG_ACTIVE});
00397     }
00398     $self->{answer_eval_count}++;
00399   }
00400   $self->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH};
00401 }
00402 
00403 
00404 =item ANS()
00405 
00406  TEXT(ans_rule(), ans_rule(), ans_rule());
00407  ANS($answer_evaluator1, $answer_evaluator2, $answer_evaluator3);
00408 
00409 Adds the answer evaluators listed to the list of unlabeled answer evaluators.
00410 They will be paired with unlabeled answer rules (a.k.a. answer blanks) in the
00411 order entered. This is the standard method for entering answers.
00412 
00413 In the above example, answer_evaluator1 will be associated with the first
00414 answer rule, answer_evaluator2 with the second, and answer_evaluator3 with the
00415 third. In practice, the arguments to ANS() will usually be calls to an answer
00416 evaluator generator such as the cmp() method of MathObjects or the num_cmp()
00417 macro in L<PGanswermacros.pl>.
00418 
00419 =cut
00420 
00421 # ^function ANS
00422 # ^uses $PG_STOP_FLAG
00423 # ^uses @PG_ANSWERS
00424 
00425 sub ANS{
00426   my $self = shift;
00427   my @in = @_;
00428   while (@in ) {
00429          # create new label
00430          $self->{unlabeled_answer_eval_count}++;
00431          my $label = $self->new_label($self->{unlabeled_answer_eval_count});
00432          my $evaluator = shift @in;
00433          $self->LABELED_ANS($label, $evaluator);
00434   }
00435   $self->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH};
00436 }
00437 
00438 
00439 
00440 
00441 =item STOP_RENDERING()
00442 
00443  STOP_RENDERING() unless all_answers_are_correct();
00444 
00445 Temporarily suspends accumulation of problem text and storing of answer blanks
00446 and answer evaluators until RESUME_RENDERING() is called.
00447 
00448 =cut
00449 
00450 # ^function STOP_RENDERING
00451 # ^uses $PG_STOP_FLAG
00452 sub STOP_RENDERING {
00453     my $self = shift;
00454     $self->{PG_ACTIVE}=0;
00455     "";
00456 }
00457 
00458 =item RESUME_RENDERING()
00459 
00460  RESUME_RENDERING();
00461 
00462 Resumes accumulating problem text and storing answer blanks and answer
00463 evaluators. Reverses the effect of STOP_RENDERING().
00464 
00465 =cut
00466 
00467 # ^function RESUME_RENDERING
00468 # ^uses $PG_STOP_FLAG
00469 sub RESUME_RENDERING {
00470     my $self = shift;
00471     $self->{PG_ACTIVE}=1;
00472     "";
00473 }

00477 sub new_label {     #creates a new label for unlabeled submissions ASNWER_PREFIX.$number
00478     my $self         = shift;
00479     my $number       = shift;
00480     $self->{QUIZ_PREFIX}.$self->{ANSWER_PREFIX}.sprintf("%04u", $number);
00481 }
00482 sub new_array_label {     #creates a new label for unlabeled submissions ASNWER_PREFIX.$number
00483     my $self         = shift;
00484     my $number       = shift;
00485     $self->{QUIZ_PREFIX}.$self->{ARRAY_PREFIX}.sprintf("%04u", $number);
00486 }
00487 sub new_array_element_label {     #creates a new label for unlabeled submissions ARRAY_PREFIX.$number
00488     my $self              = shift;
00489     my $ans_label         = shift;  # name of the PGanswer group holding this array
00490     my $row_num           = shift;
00491     my $col_num           = shift;
00492     my %options           = @_;
00493     my $vec_num           = (defined $options{vec_num})?$options{vec_num}: 0 ;
00494     $self->{QUIZ_PREFIX}.$ans_label.'__'.$vec_num.'-'.$row_num.'-'.$col_num.'__';
00495 }
00496 sub new_answer_name  {     # bit of a legacy item
00497     &new_label;
00498 }
00499 
00500 
00501 sub record_ans_name {      # the labels in the PGanswer group and response group should match in this case
00502     my $self = shift;
00503     my $label = shift;
00504     my $value = shift;
00505     #$self->internal_debug_message("PGcore::record_ans_name: $label $value");
00506     my $response_group = new PGresponsegroup($label,$label,$value);
00507     if (defined($self->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$label}) ) {
00508         $self->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$label}->replace(ans_label => $label, 
00509                                                    response  => $response_group, 
00510                                                    active    => $self->{PG_ACTIVE});
00511     } else {
00512         $self->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$label} = PGanswergroup->new($label, 
00513                                                    response  => $response_group, 
00514                                                    active    => $self->{PG_ACTIVE});
00515     }
00516     $self->{answer_blank_count}++;
00517     $label;
00518 }
00519 
00520 sub record_array_name {  # currently the same as record ans name
00521     my $self = shift;
00522     my $label = shift;
00523     my $value = shift;
00524     my $response_group = new PGresponsegroup($label,$label,$value);  
00525     if (defined($self->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$label}) ) {
00526         $self->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$label}->replace(ans_label => $label, 
00527                                                    response   => $response_group, 
00528                                                    active     => $self->{PG_ACTIVE});
00529     } else {
00530         $self->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$label} = PGanswergroup->new($label, 
00531                                                    response   => $response_group, 
00532                                                    active     => $self->{PG_ACTIVE});
00533     }
00534     $self->{answer_blank_count}++;
00535     #$self->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$label}->{response}->clear;  #why is this ?
00536     $label;
00537 
00538 }
00539 sub extend_ans_group {         # modifies the group type
00540     my $self = shift;
00541     my $label = shift;
00542     my @response_list = @_;
00543     my $answer_group  = $self->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$label};
00544     if (ref($answer_group) =~/PGanswergroup/) {
00545         $answer_group->append_responses(@response_list);
00546     } else {
00547         #$self->warning_message("The answer |$label| has not yet been defined, you cannot extend it.",caller() );
00548         # this error message is correct but misleading for the original way 
00549         # in which matrix blanks and their response evaluators are matched up
00550         # we should restore the warning message once the new matrix evaluation method is in place
00551     
00552     }
00553     $label;
00554 }
00555 sub record_unlabeled_ans_name {
00556     my $self = shift;
00557     $self->{unlabeled_answer_blank_count}++;
00558     my $label = $self->new_label($self->{unlabeled_answer_blank_count});
00559     $self->record_ans_name($label);
00560     $label;
00561 }
00562 sub record_unlabeled_array_name {
00563     my $self = shift;
00564     $self->{unlabeled_answer_blank_count}++;
00565     my $ans_label = $self->new_array_label($self->{unlabeled_answer_blank_count});
00566     $self->record_array_name($ans_label);                          
00567 }
00568 sub store_persistent_data {  # will store strings only (so far)
00569     my $self = shift;
00570     my $label = shift;
00571     my @content = @_;
00572     $self->internal_debug_message("PGcore::store_persistent_data: storing $label in PERSISTENCE_HASH");
00573     if (defined($self->{PERSISTENCE_HASH}->{$label}) ) {
00574         warn "can' overwrite $label in persistent data";
00575     } else {
00576         $self->{PERSISTENCE_HASH}->{$label} = join("",@content);  #need base64 encoding?
00577     }
00578     $label;
00579 }
00580 sub check_answer_hash {
00581     my $self = shift;
00582     foreach my $key (keys %{ $self->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH} }) {
00583         my $ans_eval = $self->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$key}->{ans_eval};
00584         unless (ref($ans_eval) =~ /CODE/ or ref($ans_eval) =~ /AnswerEvaluator/ ) {
00585             warn "The answer group labeled $key is missing an answer evaluator";
00586         }
00587         unless (ref( $self->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$key}->{response} ) =~ /PGresponsegroup/ ) {
00588             warn "The answer group labeled $key is missing answer blanks ";
00589         }
00590     }
00591 }
00592 
00593 sub PG_restricted_eval {
00594     my $self = shift;
00595     WeBWorK::PG::Translator::PG_restricted_eval(@_);
00596 }

00599 =head2 base64 coding
00600 
00601     $str       = decode_base64($coded_str);
00602     $coded_str = encode_base64($str);
00603 
00604 # Sometimes a question author needs to code or decode base64 directly
00605 
00606 =cut
00607 
00608 sub decode_base64 ($) {
00609     my $self = shift;
00610     my $str = shift;
00611     MIME::Base64::decode_base64($str);
00612 }
00613 
00614 sub encode_base64 ($;$) {
00615     my $self = shift;
00616     my $str  = shift;
00617     my $option = shift;
00618     MIME::Base64::encode_base64($str);
00619 }
00620 
00621 =head2   Message channels
00622 
00623 There are three message channels
00624     $PG->debug_message()   or in PG:  DEBUG_MESSAGE() 
00625     $PG->warning_message() or in PG:  WARNING_MESSAGE()
00626     
00627 They behave the same way, it is simply convention as to how they are used.
00628     
00629 To report the messages use:
00630 
00631     $PG->get_debug_messages
00632     $PG->get_warning_messages
00633 
00634 These are used in Problem.pm for example to report any errors.
00635 
00636 There is also
00637         
00638     $PG->internal_debug_message()
00639     $PG->get_internal_debug_message
00640     $PG->clear_internal_debug_messages();
00641     
00642 There were times when things were buggy enough that only the internal_debug_message which are not saved
00643 inside the PGcore object would report.
00644 
00645 =cut
00646 
00647 sub debug_message {
00648     my $self = shift;
00649     my @str = @_;
00650     push @{$self->{DEBUG_messages}}, "<br/>", @str;
00651 }
00652 sub get_debug_messages {
00653     my $self = shift;
00654     $self->{DEBUG_messages};
00655 }
00656 sub warning_message {
00657     my $self = shift;
00658     my @str = @_;
00659     unshift @str, "<br/>------"; # mark start of each message
00660     push @{$self->{WARNING_messages}}, @str;
00661 }
00662 sub get_warning_messages {
00663     my $self = shift;
00664     $self->{WARNING_messages};
00665 }
00666 
00667 sub internal_debug_message {
00668     my $self = shift;
00669     my @str = @_;
00670     push @{$internal_debug_messages}, @str;
00671 }
00672 sub get_internal_debug_messages {
00673     my $self = shift;
00674     $internal_debug_messages;
00675 }
00676 sub clear_internal_debug_messages {
00677     my $self = shift;
00678     $internal_debug_messages=[];
00679 }
00680 
00681 sub DESTROY {
00682     # doing nothing about destruction, hope that isn't dangerous
00683 }
00684

00686 #   warn(@_);
00687 # }

00689 
00690 # This creates on the fly graphs
00691 
00692 =head2 insertGraph
00693 
00694     # returns a path to the file containing the graph image.
00695     $filePath = insertGraph($graphObject);
00696 
00697 insertGraph writes a GIF or PNG image file to the gif subdirectory of the
00698 current course's HTML temp directory. The file name is obtained from the graph
00699 object. Warnings are issued if errors occur while writing to the file.
00700 
00701 Returns a string containing the full path to the temporary file containing the
00702 image. This is most often used in the construct
00703 
00704     TEXT(alias(insertGraph($graph)));
00705 
00706 where alias converts the directory address to a URL when serving HTML pages and
00707 insures that an EPS file is generated when creating TeX code for downloading.
00708 
00709 =cut
00710 
00711 # ^function insertGraph
00712 # ^uses $WWPlot::use_png
00713 # ^uses convertPath
00714 # ^uses surePathToTmpFile
00715 # ^uses PG_restricted_eval
00716 # ^uses $refreshCachedImages
00717 # ^uses $templateDirectory
00718 # ^uses %envir
00719 sub insertGraph {
00720     # Convert the image to GIF and print it on standard output
00721     my $self     = shift;
00722     my $graph    = shift;
00723     my $extension = ($WWPlot::use_png) ? '.png' : '.gif';
00724     my $fileName = $graph->imageName  . $extension;
00725     my $filePath = $self->convertPath("gif/$fileName");
00726     my $templateDirectory = $self->{envir}->{templateDirectory};
00727     $filePath = $self->surePathToTmpFile( $filePath );
00728     my $refreshCachedImages = $self->PG_restricted_eval(q!$refreshCachedImages!);
00729     # Check to see if we already have this graph, or if we have to make it
00730     if( not -e $filePath # does it exist?
00731       or ((stat "$templateDirectory"."$main::envir{fileName}")[9] > (stat $filePath)[9]) # source has changed
00732       or $graph->imageName =~ /Undefined_Set/ # problems from SetMaker and its ilk should always be redone
00733       or $refreshCachedImages
00734     ) {
00735         #createFile($filePath, $main::tmp_file_permission, $main::numericalGroupID);
00736         local(*OUTPUT);  # create local file handle so it won't overwrite other open files.
00737         open(OUTPUT, ">$filePath")||warn ("$0","Can't open $filePath<BR>","");
00738         chmod( 0777, $filePath);
00739         print OUTPUT $graph->draw|| warn("$0","Can't print graph to $filePath<BR>","");
00740         close(OUTPUT)||warn("$0","Can't close $filePath<BR>","");
00741     }
00742     $filePath;
00743 }

00801 
00802 =head2 surePathToTmpFile
00803 
00804     $path = surePathToTmpFile($path);
00805 
00806 Creates all of the intermediate directories between the tempDirectory 
00807 
00808 If $path begins with the tempDirectory path, then the
00809 path is treated as absolute. Otherwise, the path is treated as relative the the
00810 course temp directory.
00811 
00812 =cut
00813 
00814 # A very useful macro for making sure that all of the directories to a file have been constructed.
00815 
00816 # ^function surePathToTmpFile
00817 # ^uses getCourseTempDirectory
00818 # ^uses createDirectory
00819 
00820 
00821 sub surePathToTmpFile {
00822     # constructs intermediate directories if needed beginning at ${Global::htmlDirectory}tmp/
00823     # the input path must be either the full path, or the path relative to this tmp sub directory
00824     
00825     my $self = shift;
00826     my $path = shift;
00827     my $delim = "/"; 
00828     my $tmpDirectory = $self->tempDirectory();
00829     unless ( -e $tmpDirectory) {   # if by some unlucky chance the tmpDirectory hasn't been created, create it.
00830         my $parentDirectory =  $tmpDirectory;
00831         $parentDirectory =~s|/$||;  # remove a trailing /
00832         $parentDirectory = $self->directoryFromPath($parentDirectory);
00833         my ($perms, $groupID) = (stat $parentDirectory)[2,5];
00834         #warn "Creating tmp directory at $tmpDirectory, perms $perms groupID $groupID";
00835         $self->createDirectory($tmpDirectory, $perms, $groupID)
00836                 or warn "Failed to create parent tmp directory at $path";
00837     
00838     }
00839     # use the permissions/group on the temp directory itself as a template
00840     my ($perms, $groupID) = (stat $tmpDirectory)[2,5];
00841     #warn "surePathToTmpFile: directory=$tmpDirectory, perms=$perms, groupID=$groupID\n";
00842     
00843     # if the path starts with $tmpDirectory (which is permitted but optional) remove this initial segment
00844     $path =~ s|^$tmpDirectory|| if $path =~ m|^$tmpDirectory|;
00845     
00846     # find the nodes on the given path
00847         my @nodes = split("$delim",$path);
00848     
00849     # create new path
00850     $path = $tmpDirectory; 
00851     
00852     while (@nodes>1) {
00853         $path = $path . shift (@nodes) . "/"; #convertPath($path . shift (@nodes) . "/");
00854 
00855         unless (-e $path) {
00856             $self->createDirectory($path, $perms, $groupID)
00857                 or $self->warning_message( "Failed to create directory at $path with permissions $perms and groupID $groupID");
00858         }
00859 
00860     }
00861     
00862     $path = $path . shift(@nodes); #convertPath($path . shift(@nodes));
00863     return $path;
00864 }
